Package battleship

Class Ocean

java.lang.Object
battleship.Ocean
public class Ocean
extends java.lang.Object
This contains a 10x10 array of Ships, representing an “ocean”, and some methods to manipulate it
Author:
sobpark

  • Field Summary

    Fields 
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    private static java.util.ArrayList<Ship> allShips
    arraylist ship to include all ships in the game
    static java.lang.String[][] grid
    empty 10x10 grid for the sea for print
    private int hitCount
    The number of times a shot hit a ship.
    private Ship[][] ships
    Used to quickly determine which ship is in any given location 10x10 grid
    private int shipsSunk
    The number of ships sunk (10 ships in all)
    private int shotsFired
    The total number of shots fired by the user

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    Ocean()
    Creates an ”empty” ocean (and fills the ships array with EmptySea objects).

    Prints the Ocean.To aid the user,row numbers should be displayed along the left edge of the array, and column numbers should be displayed along the top.

    set illegal location in adjacent area around ships placed in ocean this will flag as invalid for okToPlaceShipAt method so that no ships are placed

  • Field Details

    • ships

      private Ship[][] ships
      Used to quickly determine which ship is in any given location 10x10 grid

    • grid

      public static java.lang.String[][] grid
      empty 10x10 grid for the sea for print

    • shotsFired

      private int shotsFired
      The total number of shots fired by the user

    • hitCount

      private int hitCount
      The number of times a shot hit a ship. If the user shoots the same part of a ship more than once, every hit is counted, even though additional “hits” don’t do the user any good

    • shipsSunk

      private int shipsSunk
      The number of ships sunk (10 ships in all)

    • allShips

      private static java.util.ArrayList<Ship> allShips
      arraylist ship to include all ships in the game

  • Constructor Details

    • Ocean

      public Ocean()
      Creates an ”empty” ocean (and fills the ships array with EmptySea objects). You could create a private helper method to do this. Also initializes any game variables, such as how many shots have been fired

  • Method Details

    • emptyOceanArray

      private Ship[][] emptyOceanArray()
      creates an empty start array
      Returns:
      ships array for empty ocean array

    • getShipArray

      public Ship[][] getShipArray()
      Returns the 10x10 array of Ships. The methods in the Ship class that take an Ocean parameter need to be able to look at the contents of this array; the placeShipAt() method even needs to modify it While it is undesirable to allow methods in one class to directly access instance variables in another class, sometimes there is just no good alternative
      Returns:
      the 10x10 array of Ships

    • getAllShips

      public static java.util.ArrayList<Ship> getAllShips()
      all ships list getter for testing
      Returns:
      allShips arraylist

    • getShotsFired

      public int getShotsFired()
      Returns the number of shots fired (in the game)
      Returns:
      number of shots

    • getHitCount

      public int getHitCount()
      Returns the number of hits recorded (in the game). All hits are counted, not just the first time a given square is hit
      Returns:
      number of hits recorded

    • getShipsSunk

      public int getShipsSunk()
      Returns the number of ships sunk (in the game)
      Returns:
      number of ships sunk

    • setIllegalLocation

      public void setIllegalLocation()
      set illegal location in adjacent area around ships placed in ocean this will flag as invalid for okToPlaceShipAt method so that no ships are placed

    • setShipArray

      public void setShipArray​(int row, int column, Ship ship)
      puts the ship on a location in the ocean
      Parameters:
      row - for ship
      column - for ship
      ship - on a given location

    • placeAllShipsRandomly

      public void placeAllShipsRandomly()
      Place all ten ships randomly on the (initially empty) ocean. Place larger ships before smaller ones, or you may end up with no legal place to put a large ship. You will want to use the Random class in the java.util package, so look that up in the Java API.

    • direction

      private boolean direction()
      randomly determines direction of the ship
      Returns:
      random direction

    • isOccupied

      public boolean isOccupied​(int row, int column)
      Returns true if the given location contains a ship, false if it does not
      Parameters:
      row - for given location
      column - for given location
      Returns:
      true if the given location contains a ship, false if it does not

    • shootAt

      public boolean shootAt​(int row, int column)
      Returns true if the given location contains a ”real” ship, still afloat, (not an EmptySea), false if it does not. In addition, this method updates the number of shots that have been fired, and the number of hits. Note: If a location contains a “real” ship, shootAt should return true every time the user shoots at that same location. Once a ship has been ”sunk”, additional shots at its location should return false
      Parameters:
      row - to shoot at
      column - to shoot at
      Returns:
      true if the given location contains a ”real” ship, still afloat, (not an EmptySea), false if it does not

    • isGameOver

      public boolean isGameOver()
      Returns true if all ships have been sunk, otherwise false
      Returns:
      true if all ships are sunk

    • hitOnShip

      public boolean hitOnShip​(int row, int col)
      check if there is a hit at a certain location
      Parameters:
      row - for shot
      col - for shot
      Returns:
      boolean true for true hit, false for no hit in ship

    • print

      public void print()
      Prints the Ocean.To aid the user,row numbers should be displayed along the left edge of the array, and column numbers should be displayed along the top. Numbers should be 0 to 9, not 1 to 10
